lines.text: I need to use your bathroom.
No!
What am I supposed to do, shit outside?
Lincoln did.
If you fix one shitty toilet, I'll disown you. One toilet, you're out of the will!
[grabs the heater Tito is carrying]
Give me that, Buckwheat!
Who you calling 'Buckwheat', you fat fuck.
Beautiful. A fucking sink that farts.
You want your electricity fixed? Move. Check into the fucking Plaza, just gimmie the rent Lady!
Look at my boy. How's he supposed to do his schoolwork at night? By candle light?
Lincoln did. Hey maybe he'll grown up to be president, what the fuck do I know? Just gimmie the rent!
Here, run this up to the house, and here's a fin.
Thank you.
Thank you? That's it? That's five dollars I gave you.
Thank you, master, thank you master.
Fuck you, kid.
Fuck you too.
Heather, can I ask you something? How far did you go in school?
Oh, well when I was in high school I wouldn't even let a guy touch me. But when I got to community college, I turned pretty wild.
Why do they call you Milkman?
Because I killed the milkman.

Let me explain something to you, son. You fix this place up on Monday, Friday it's back the way it was. You put in plumbing, they put chicken bones down the toilet. Put in heat, they piss in the hot air ducts!
What is that smell? It smells like...
Piss.
Yeah, smells like piss, what is it?
It's piss. Drunks come in the hallway and they piss.
You let them pee in here?
It's not like they ask permission.
Why is that you have twenty-four different kinds of pork rinds and you only have one kind of peanut butter?
Because we don't get too many fussy little white pricks in here.
Okay.
At least there's a Motif - WALL TO WALL SHIT!
How is my boy supposed to do his schoolwork at night? By candle light?
Lincoln did. Maybe he'll grow up to be president, what the fuck do I know?
No way I'm going to that shit hole.
Who are you talking to?
Heather, trying to figure out where to go tonight.
I'll tell you where you're going tonight. You're going to the building to serve your time or else you're going to jail.
It worked before you broke it!
English! English! Doesn't anybody talk English?
It's only lights.
Only lights? That's the inch, now they'll want the mile. You give them shit! That's what you give them, shit! Shit!
Miss Bensinger, you're just in time to see my agenda.
Oh yes. Where is it?

[Points to crotch]
Right here.

[Leaving]
I think the judge was looking for something a bit bigger, Mr. Kritski.
Will you stop about the tenants? Remember, they used to live in huts. They used to eat people. You feel better now? Hey, come on, who gives a shit about a few whiny kookaboos?
Therefore, I find Louis Kritski Jr. guilty.
I'm gonna get a new lawyer, a white judge and an appeal.
On what grounds?
On the grounds that you piss me off.
Do you know what kind of droppings those are?
Moose droppings.
Rat droppings, Kritski.
You really know your shit, don't you? Ha ha ha ha. What's the matter? You got no sense of humor?
So what are you gonna do about it?
Nothing. If they pay the rent, they can stay!

[Louie is distributing heaters to the tenants at Big Lou's expense]
They've brain washed you. Like Patty Hearst. What's next? You gonna rig it into a Disney World?
Pop...
Don't call me 'Pop'. I don't recognize you anymore. You're not my son. You're breaking my heart!
I've called every heating contractor in the city. They're all booked solid. It's winter! What do you want me to do? Go out and kidnap one and drag him back here?
Yeah.
I won't! If I can tough it out, so can you people.
How are we supposed to keep warm in the mean time?
Burn one of your kids. What do I care?
[slams the door]
Damn! Boy, Big Lou was right about those shitheads. If they wanna keep warm, why don't they dance. Ha ha.

[Leotha stands in the doorway]
Out of the way, Leotha, this is an emergency.
Uh uh. Not 'til you tell me when you're gonna fix the boiler in the building.
There's nothing wrong with the boiler in the building. It's running, ain't it?
Yeah. All the way up to forty degrees. I am freezing.
Get a man.
Up yours, Kritski.
GOSH, LIFE STINKS!
And then you die!
I'm doubling your rent, meathead!
Good. That makes two bad checks I have to write!

[Louie appears, wearing a hooded sweatshirt and pump sneakers]
If you think I look stupid, just say so, Marlon.
I don't think you look stupid.
Then what are you looking at? The jacket? The hood? What?

It screams. You know what it says? It says, "Look at me! I'm wearing shit that nobody else in this neighborhood would wear. So come and stick me with a sharp object of your preference and then steal that hide-away wallet I got velcroed to my leg".
You could tell?
No, it doesn't show. But that's what you guys usually wear.
Alright, get off my roof before there's trouble.
There's already trouble.
I'll throw you right the fuck off this roof!
Yeah, you and who else?

[entering]
Me.

[enters behind Marlon]
Me too.

[enters]
Me too, shit-head.
Wat are you, spying on me?
No.
You casing this joint so the brothers can rob it later?

[sarcastically]
Yeah, you really got some choice stuff here. We can't wait to get our hands on it.
How come you're not in school, kid?
It's Saturday.
Yeah? Then why aren't you out playing basketball or break dancing?
I prayed for you last night, Mr. Kristki. I prayed for you to get my commode fixed.
Get out of my way and leave me alone!
You don't want me to leave you alone.
Trust me, I do.
No, Satan wants me to leave you alone.
We BOTH want you to leave me alone. Ha ha. Hallelujah.
Neighbor.
Neighbor? You're late with your rent, Marlon. I know, I know, Mommy's dying again, you had to send money. How many times is it this year Mamacita's almost croaked?
Six. But you know, I am glad she is still with us.

Listen, why don't you insure the lady? This way when she decides to join that big Piñata party in the sky, you can use the insurance money to pay your rent. Know what I mean? What is it with you Latins, don't you have any pride?
I got pride. I'm proud I live in a building. I'm proud I don't live in a cardboard box. I have an address I can't afford. I'm proud of that.
Okay, one down, 63 to go. Here you go, Louie.
You're a buck short, Dad.
No it's all there. Take another look, you may have missed something.
Dad.
January is a very tough month.
So is December. Give me my money.
That's my boy!

[narrating]
Yeah, Sundays were always the best.

[arriving at the apartment house at night for the first time]
Jesus. You know what, I think this is gonna be okay. It's gonna be like camp. I'll watch TV, I'll sleep, I'll hang out with Heather. Heather's gotta come over. How bad can it be? I'll have Heather.
[Looks up at the building]
How the hell am I going to do this? Twenty seven buildings worth millions of dollars, you could fucking do this.
Hey, put that shit down! Put it down!
Fuck you.
No fuck you! There's not gonna be a fire.
You must be Junior. Well, Junior, your old man over there paid me alot of money to light this place up. And that's what I'm gonna do.
Well what do you need?
Okay, let's see... I got my girl coming over. I'll need some wine. What kind of wine do you got here? You got any...
[the storekeeper places a small bottle of screw-top wine on the counter]
What the fuck is that? You expect me to drink screw-top wine?
You want a buzz? It's gonna have to come from this.
Better just get some essentials so I don't starve to death.
[Grabs a loaf of bread places it on the counter with a 'THUNK']
Holy shit! Your bread's older than your fucking wine. Ha ha ha ha ha ha. This is aged. This should - -See, this should be aged
[about the wine]
You don't - You get it? What a sense of humor. Am I on Candid Camera in this place or what?
Obviously it's unusually cold in the building today. Not necessarily due to a malfunction of our boiler.
That piece of shit it totally gone!
You can't prove that.
Prove it? My parakeet is frozen solid. I could crack walnuts with him!
You deadeat son of a bitch, where's the rent?
I'm a little short right now. How about another week?
Another week? Another week? What do you say, Louie, shall we give him another week?
Eh... okay.

Okay? Really? Are you sure? Remember, that $3.00 I give you every week really isn't an allowance, it's more like a percentage. You let this guy skate, that means you only get $2.70. Now remember, the other tenants are gonna want another week. You know what that means? Pretty soon you'll be down to nothing, zero zip. No ice cream. No soda. No candy...
[turns to shout at tenant]
YOU GONNA STEAL CANDY FROM MY KID'S MOUTH?
No, man, no.
Then give me what you got. Alright, Friday, Willie, I want the rest Friday.
[He and Louie leave]

[mutters]
Don't hold your breath.
